presentation.title: Flood regulation
presentation.runninghead: The role of nature in protecting people and assets from floods

page.name: Flood regulation
page.title: Model coverage and general information
page.description:
To better idenfify the distinct economic benefits and ecological processes related to disturbance regulation, we separately consider the protection of life and property from flooding along rivers, flooding in coastal zones, and prevention of landslides, mudslides, or avalanches. This module assembles all the storylines related to for flood regulationin the user-defined region.

Ecological restoration focused on improving flood regulation can provide a range of co-beneficial ecosystem services, which can be simulated using scenarios in the ARIES flood model and other relevant ecosystem services models. For instance, reconnecting rivers to floodplains through levee setbacks can provide a wide range of economic benefits from ecosystem services. ARIES provides a missing spatial planning tool to explore tradeoffs between multiple ecosystem services associated with forest management and other flood mitigation projects.

The ARIES flood models start by mapping sources of precipitation, which can cause floods, “sinks” that absorb, detain, or promote infiltration of floodwater, and the location of beneficiaries at risk of flooding that may receive flood mitigation benefits. Sink models incorporate vegetation and soils data that describes how well different areas can promote infiltration, as well as the location of engineered flood control infrastructure such as dams and detention basins. Flood flow models spatially link sources of floodwater, beneficial sinks, and beneficiaries in the landscape. These flow models account for the location and width of floodplains and the effects of levees, which both protect assets at risk behind levees and speed the flow of water downstream, potentially increasing downstream damage. Different beneficiary groups may be protected from flooding – crops, privately owned housing or other buildings, publicly owned infrastructure, and human life. GIS data showing riverine flood zones and maps of population, agriculture, and structures allows beneficiaries to be mapped.

The ARIES flood regulation model currently operates using annual data for precipitation, runoff, infiltration, and evapotranspiration (measured in mm/yr). While modeling specific flood events) would be desirable, the data needed to populate these models at such time scales is rarely available. The current ARIES flood models can thus be used to explore general flood vulnerability, the beneficiaries of flood regulation, and the effects of flood mitigation alternatives (e.g., forest management, levee setbacks) on provision of flood regulation plus other co-benefit ecosystem services.
